item.title: project pegasus
item.description: Pegasus is a blockchain protocol that generates verified credentials for each digitally verifiable task (or set of) that an individual completes, proving the value they have added to the world. problem descriptor Growing demand for jobs in companies that are growing, paired with a limited supply, leads to increasingly standardized testing processes in recruiting that are long, repetitive, generate no value, and consequently allow fabricated experience to be considered.

item.title: text
item.description: Readings Currently Reading: Surely You’re Joking, Mr. Feynman! Previously Read: Title Author Siddhartha Hermann Hesse Quantum Computing Since Democritus Scott Aaronson What We Owe The Future William MacAskhill Quantum Computing for Everyone Chris Bernhardt Fundraising Ryan Breslow The Return of the King J.R.R Tolkein Elon Musk: Tesla, SpaceX and the Quest for a Fantastic Future Ashlee Vance Foundation’s Edge Isaac Asimov You can find a more detailed list of my readings on my Notion.

item.title: timeline
item.description: üìÑ Resume 2023 Study Abroad @Graz University of Technology , Graz Austria Feb. 2023 - Jun. 2023 Courses: NLP, GPU Programming, Recommender Systems, Social Media Technologies, Data Science & AI 2022 Software Engineering Intern @Staax , San Francisco CA Jun. 2022 - Jan. 2023 Formulated company financials and metrics calculation scripts for CAC, lifetime value, DAU, MAU, churn and conversions, and created summary reports on Google Analytics for investors by collaborating closely with Staax executives.

item.title: about me
item.description: “Finished products are for decadent minds.” - Bail Channis, Second Foundation Hi üëã I’m Rohit, a fourth year Computer Science undergrad at the University of Waterloo. Originally, I come from Bangalore, India, informally known as the Silicon Valley of India, and rightly so in my opinion. I witnessed the growth of myriad small businesses1 (into large national and multi-national corporations) throughout my childhood, and thought to myself, “If they can do it, why not me?
